de.uni.bamberg.wiai.minf.forflow.datagenerator.controller.datageneration.distribution
Class UniformDistribution

java.lang.Object
  de.uni.bamberg.wiai.minf.forflow.datagenerator.controller.datageneration.distribution.ProbabilityDistribution
      de.uni.bamberg.wiai.minf.forflow.datagenerator.controller.datageneration.distribution.UniformDistribution
All Implemented Interfaces:
ObservableDistribution, ObserverFillBehaviour, java.lang.Cloneable
public class UniformDistribution
extends ProbabilityDistribution

X ~ U(a, b)

An uniform probability distribution can be either discrete or continuous. We use the discrete uniform distribution.

Probability density
The probability of any outcome k_i is 1/n. All values of a set of possible values are equally. The probability density function f(x) is a constant value.

Parameters
The uniform distribution is defined by two parameters, a and b. A tells where the lower bound is and b where the upper bound is. If X follows a uniform distribution then
  • f(x) = 1/(b - a) where a ≤ x ≤ b
  • E(X) = (a + b)/2
  • Var(X) = (b - a)²/12

Since:
Apr/20/09
Version:
0.1
Author:
Michael Munz

Method Detail

generatorInt

public org.uncommons.maths.number.NumberGenerator<java.lang.Integer> generatorInt(java.util.Random random)
Description copied from class: ProbabilityDistribution
creates a random number generator. Random number generators help us to generate a sequence of independent random numbers with a specified distribution. It's important to make distinction between random numbers and pseudo random numbers.

Random numbers
Truly random numbers must introduce some non-deterministic input. Some real world phenomenon that is unpredictable. Computer are deterministic and they're generally incapable of doing things at random.

Pseudo random numbers
Since computer cannot generate random numbers, the idea is, for a given probability distribution, to develop an algorithm such that the numbers appear to be random with the specified distribution. So pseudo random numbers are not really random at all. They are the result of deterministic mathematical formulae. Pseudo random number generators (PRNG) start with a single numeric seed value.

Specified by:
generatorInt in class ProbabilityDistribution
Parameters:
random - any PRNG which extends Random interface of the Java.util.Random can be plugged in.
Returns:
Interface for providing different types of sequences of numbers

generateExpectedValues

public java.util.Map<java.lang.Double,java.lang.Double> generateExpectedValues()
Description copied from class: ProbabilityDistribution
this method generates the expected values for any probability distribution. Expected values form the shape of a probability distribution, like the bell curve of a normal distribution.

Visualizing
This method is intended to support in the decision of choosing the right probability distribution by visualizing it.

X, P(X=x)
X is a variate and follows any probability distribution with the probability P(X=x).

Specified by:
generateExpectedValues in class ProbabilityDistribution
Returns:
Map(X, P(X=x))

getExpectation

public int getExpectation()
Expectation gives a prediction of the results. The expectation of a variable X is like the mean, but for probability distributions. The expectation gives the typical or average value of a variable but it doesn't tell anything about how the values are spread out.

Specified by:
getExpectation in class ProbabilityDistribution
Returns:
E(X) = (a + b) / 2

getStandardDeviation

public int getStandardDeviation()
Description copied from class: ProbabilityDistribution
As well as having a variance, probability distributions have a standard deviation. It's a way of measuring how far away from the center you can expect your values to be.

σ = √Var(X)

Specified by:
getStandardDeviation in class ProbabilityDistribution
Returns:
σ = √Var(X)

getVariance

public double getVariance()
Use variance to measure the spread of values. In other words, variance tells you about the spread of the result.

Specified by:

Returns:
Var(X) = (b - a)² / 12

isDiscrete

public boolean isDiscrete()
Description copied from class: ProbabilityDistribution
Distributions
In general probability distributions are divided in two subsets:
  • discrete probability distribution
  • continuous probability distribution
Discrete Probability
A discrete probability function can take a discrete number of values. This means that it can only take exact values. Each of these discrete values has a certain probability of occurrence that is between [0, 1]. That is, a discrete function that allows negative values or values greater than one is not a probability distribution.

Continuous Probability
A continuous probability function can take countless values. It's frequently data that is measured in some way rather than counted, and a lot depends on the degree of precision you need to measure to. Continuous data is like a smooth, continuous path. With this probability function you need to focus on a particular level of accuracy and the probability of getting a range of values..

Specified by:
isDiscrete in class ProbabilityDistribution
Returns:
true, if discrete

registerObserverDistribution

public void registerObserverDistribution(ObserverDistribution observer)
Description copied from interface: ObservableDistribution
When an observer registers, it's just added to the end of the obersver list.

Parameters:
observer - an object to notify when a change occurs. In terms of probability distributions, a change means either its created or eliminated.

removeObserverDistribution

public void removeObserverDistribution(ObserverDistribution observer)
Description copied from interface: ObservableDistribution
Likewise, when an observer wants to un-register we just take it off the list.

Parameters:
observer - an object which doesn't want any notifications about its subject anymore.

notifyObserverDistribution

public void notifyObserverDistribution(boolean add)
Description copied from interface: ObservableDistribution
Here's the fun part; this is where we tell all observers about the state. Because they are all Observers, we know how to notify them.

Note, this observable is different in same kind. In other words, we use the observable to notify about its availability and not about changes in the structure.

Parameters:
add - two distinct operations are available and possible.
  • add
    • This operation is straightforward and the subject indicates about that, if the flag is set to true.
  • remove
    • It is also possible that a subject notifies about removing it from the view layer. This only happens when the controller layer eliminates the probability distribution from the model layer. The probability distribution sends an notification to all its observers that is is gonna be removed. The view layer in turn can take proper actions and react to that with removing the corresponding probability distribution from the UI list. So users can't get in trouble selecting not available probability distributions. Here not available means in terms of the model layer, of course.
